%text \textbf{Continuity at $x=a$} A function $f(x)$ is continuous at a point $x=a$ if \[ \qquad \lim_{x\to a^-} f(x) = \lim_{x\to a^+}f(x) = f(a)\]
In other words, $f(x)$ is continous at $x=a$ if it \underline\text{converges to the value} of $f(x)$ at $x=a$ from both the left and the right of $x=a$
\textbf{Continuity in $(b,c)$} A function is continuous \underline\text{in an interval} $(b,c)$ if it is continuous \underline\text{at every $a\in(b,c)$}
\textbf{Continuity in $[b,c]$} $x=b$ and $x=c$ are allowed in a closed interval like $[b,c]$. Hence, the condition for continuity needs to be modified slightly
$f(x)$ is continuous in $[b,c]$ if
$\quad\bullet$ $f(x)$ is continuous in $ (b,c)$ $\quad\bullet$ \[ \lim_{x\to b^+} f(x) = f(b) \] $\quad\bullet$ \[ \lim_{x\to c^-} f(x) = f(c) \] %
